review.title: Using Natural Language Processing to Screen Patients with Active Heart Failure: An Exploration for Hospital-wide Surveillance
review.abstract: In this paper, we proposed two different approaches, a rule-based approach and a machine-learning based approach, to identify active heart failure cases automatically by analyzing electronic health records (EHR). For the rule-based approach, we extracted cardiovascular data elements from clinical notes and matched patients to different colors according their heart failure condition by using rules provided by experts in heart failure. It achieved 69.4% accuracy and 0.729 F1-Score. For the machine learning approach, with bigram of clinical notes as features, we tried four different models while SVM with linear kernel achieved the best performance with 87.5% accuracy and 0.86 F1-Score. Also, from the classification comparison between the four different models, we believe that linear models fit better for this problem. Once we combine the machine-learning and rule-based algorithms, we will enable hospital-wide surveillance of active heart failure through increased accuracy and interpretability of the outputs.

metadata.title: Using Natural Language Processing to Screen Patients with Active Heart Failure: An Exploration for Hospital-wide Surveillance

sections.text: In this paper, we proposed two different approaches, a rules-based approach and a machine learning-based approach to automatically identify active heart failure cases by analyzing electronic medical records (EHR). For the rules-based approach, we extracted elements of cardiovascular data from clinical notes and adjusted patients according to their heart failure disease using rules provided by heart failure experts. It achieved an accuracy of 69.4% and an F1 score of 0.729. For the machine learning approach with Bigram clinical notes as characteristics, we tried four different models, while linear-core SVM with 87.5% accuracy and 0.86 F1 score achieved the best performance. Also, from the classification comparison between the four different models, we believe that linear models are better suited to this problem. By combining machine learning and rules-based algorithms, we will enable hospital-wide cardiac insufficiency monitoring and increased interoperability.

sections.heading: Problem
sections.text: We identified 3,867 patients admitted to Northwestern Memorial Hospital between August and September 2015 with a possible diagnosis of heart failure. This initial screen was conducted using a query from the Enterprise Data Warehouse to identify patients with a possible acute heart failure exacerbation. This screen primarily detects patients based on intravenous diuretics (used to draw fluid from patients with constipation) or blood tests indicating heart failure (brain-natural peptide above 100 ng / dl). The results of this EDW query were manually classified by a cardiologist and a nurse, both experts in identifying patients with potential heart failure. sections.heading: System Overview
sections.text: To separate the system into simpler parts, we split our classification system into four components - a rules-based classifier and a machine learning-based classifier. For the two classifiers, all we needed to do was change the implementation of the second and third components in their pipelines. That is, for the rules-based approach, we first extracted data elements and assigned patients to colors according to specific rules. For the machine learning approach, we created functions for all patients "notes to create a feature matrix and then trained several models on this feature matrix. The entire workflow can be described as follows: 1. The Profile Builder analyzes the raw data to the patient profile, which is an aggregated JSON matrix that contains all of his / her information. With this profile, we will be able to perform analyses against each patient.

sections.heading: Profile Builder
sections.text: NMEDW's raw data are clinical notes created by various physicians, nurses and related health professionals who care for a patient during a particular hospital stay. As we perform the analysis for each patient, we have created a profile for each patient by aggregating all of their information into a JSON file that contains all of the patient's clinical notes.

sections.heading: Rule Based Approach
sections.text: The rules-based approach performs the classification by extracting the correct data elements from patients "notes and allocating the data elements to specific classes according to specific rules. sections.heading: Machine Learning-Based Approach
sections.text: Features. Feature selection8-10 is very important in machine learning. In this approach, we experimented with several features, including n-grams and UMLS concepts derived from cTAKES, 11, etc., for each of the clinical notes in addition to the structured fields for each patient. Before extracting the features, we also performed pre-processing steps, such as removing stopwords, removing short words with less than four characters and replacing all numbers with a placeholder "NUM." Then, we built feature matrix for each patient against these features. Model training. We used 10-fold cross-validation to train and evaluate the classifiers at the patient level. In this approach, we chose four machine learning models, including Naïve Bayes, 12 SVM with RBF kernel, SVM with linear kernel, 13 and logistic regression, 14 to test their performance kit and then choose the first source of the problem by fixing the classifier.

sections.heading: Discussion
sections.text: We can make several important observations from the classification of rule-based approach and machine learning-based approach. For the rule-based approach, the accuracy of the green class (the patient has active heart failure, but no cardiology service is consulted) is low, since many gray records (the patient does not have heart failure) are wrongly classified as green. This is intentional in designing the algorithm, because it is clinically more important to capture all cases of heart failure, even at the expense of misclassifying cases without heart failure as active heart failure. Accuracy can be improved by further work in identifying words in the documentation that represent heart failure, as well as extracting concepts that highlight the severity of the condition. In addition, the prediction is likely to be significantly improved with the improvement and better use of NLP algorithms for context recognition, so that we are better able to ascertain timing hypotheses for heart failure or general-purpose clinical solution18.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text: Based on our findings, we conclude that the machine learning approach performs better than the rules-based approach with an accuracy of 87.5% compared to 69.4%. However, our implementation of the rules-based approach is not complete. We believe that it could be improved by classification rules learned from machine learning algorithms. Combined, both algorithms will not only improve outcomes to ensure that the system will be useful for hospital-wide monitoring of active heart failure, but will also make the classifications interpretable.
